description: From Old French reputer, from Latin reputo (“I count over, reckon, calculate, compute, think over, consider”), from re- (“again”) + puto (“I think”).

examples: At half-past nine on this Saturday evening, the parlour of the Salutation Inn, High Holborn, contained most of its customary visitors. […] In former days every tavern of repute kept such a room for its own select circle, a club, or society, of habitués, who met every evening, for a pipe and a cheerful glass.

verbs.description: repute (third-person singular simple present reputes, present participle reputing, simple past and past participle reputed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To attribute or credit something to something; to impute.
(transitive) To consider, think, esteem, reckon (a person or thing) to be, or as being, something
examples: Wherefore are we counted as beasts, and reputed vile in your sight?
